context: The rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis is catalyzed by 3-hydroxy-3-methyl-glutaryl coenzyme A (HMG4-CoA) reductase which reduces HMG-CoA to mevalonate and CoA. Production of isoprene (2-methyl-l,3-butadiene) which is a major component of human breath from mevalonate has been demonstrated in rat liver cytosol. In fact earlier studies have shown reduction of breath isoprene level with administration of an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor or high cholesterol diet which can suppress endogenous cholesterol synthesis despite their divergent effects on serum cholesterol level. Together these observations demonstrate the link between cholesterol biosynthesis and isoprene production. Elevation of breath isoprene content in our CKD animals was associated with significant increase in serum cholesterol level. Hypercholesterolemia in this model is, in part, due to the associated proteinuria which is known to increase cholesterol production and serum cholesterol level. The elevation of exhaled breath isoprene found in the CKD rats is consistent with earlier studies by Capodicasa et al. who found marked increase in exhaled isoprene in patients with end-stage renal disease and its further rise after hemodialysis procedure.

Additionally, elevated breath isoprene levels in chronic kidney disease (CKD) animals correlate with increased serum cholesterol, indicating that isoprene production is linked to cholesterol metabolism and may serve as a biomarker for cholesterol synthesis activity.
